[[Colonial Athletic Association|CAA]] (2007âpresent) | FirstYear = 1893 | AthlDirectorDisp = Terry Driscoll | AthlDirectorLink = Terry Driscoll | WebsiteName = TribeAthletics.com | WebsiteURL = http://www.tribeathletics.com/sports.php/5/1/ | ATWins = 542 | ATLosses = 517 | ATTies = 41 | BowlWins = 1 | BowlLosses = 2 | BowlTies = | NatlTitles = 0 | ConfTitles = 12 | Heismans = | AllAmericans = | Color1 = Green | Color1Hex = 006400 | Color2 = Gold | Color2Hex = FFD700 | FightSong = ''[[Tribe Fight Song]]'' | MascotDisplay = | MascotLink = | MarchingBand = | PagFreeLabel = Outfitter | PagFreeValue = [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] | PagFreeLabel2 = Rivals | PagFreeValue2 = [[Delaware Fightin' Blue Hens football|Delaware Fightin' Blue Hens]]

[[Old Dominion Monarchs football|Old Dominion Monarchs]] }} The '''William & Mary Tribe''' are a [[college football]] team representing the [[College of William & Mary]] in [[Williamsburg, Virginia|Williamsburg]], [[Virginia]]. William & Mary currently competes in the [[Colonial Athletic Association]] of the [[NCAA]]'s [[Division I (NCAA)#Football Championship Subdivision|Division I Football Championship Subdivision]]. As of 2010, [[Jimmye Laycock]] is in his 31st year as the Tribe's head coach. Laycock is a W&M alumnus and played [[quarterback]] under legendary college football coaches [[Marv Levy]] and [[Lou Holtz]]. William & Mary's traditional rival in football is the [[University of Richmond]]. William & Mary and Richmond have met 119 times since 1898, making the rivalry (sometimes referred to as "the South's oldest rivalry") the fourth most-played in Division I college football. Only [[The Rivalry (Lehigh-Lafayette)|LafayetteâLehigh]], [[Princeton University|Princeton]]â[[Yale University|Yale]], and [[The Game (Harvard-Yale)|HarvardâYale]] have played more games. The winner of this annual W&MâRichmond match-up, named for the last two Virginia state capitals, Richmond and Williamsburg, claims the [[Capital Cup]] (previously known as the I-64 Trophy). In 2008, William & Mary opened the [[Jimmye Laycock Football Center]], a state-of-the-art facility housing the Tribe locker room, football players' classroom study sessions and tape review rooms. The College of William & Mary has transitioned through several official nicknames since its athletic program began in 1893. From 1893 to 1916, William & Mary football players were known as the '''Orange and White''' because those were the old official school colors. From 1916 to 1977, all William & Mary athletes were known as the '''Indians'''. And, most recently, from 1978 to the present day they have been known as the '''Tribe'''. ==Results== The [[William & Mary Tribe]] football team has had unparallelled success during Jimmye Laycock's tenure. Since his taking over as head coach, W&M have enjoyed winning seasons nearly every year. The long-time head-coach has led the Tribe to multiple playoff appearances, including the national semifinal game on two occasions. Most recently, the Tribe reached the semifinal against eventual champions Villanova in 2009, losing by a single point. The team has also appeared in three bowl games: the [[1948 Dixie Bowl]], [[Delta Bowl|1949 Delta Bowl]] and [[1970 Tangerine Bowl]]. The Tribe are 1â2 in those games, with the lone win being a 20â0 victory over [[Oklahoma State Cowboys football|Oklahoma A&M]] in 1949. ==Tribe currently in the NFL== ===Coaches=== #[[Mark Duffner]] (Class of 1975) â Linebackers coach for the [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] #[[Ivan Fears]] (Class of 1976) â Running backs coach for the [[New England Patriots]] #[[Sean McDermott]] (Class of 1998) â Defensive coordinator of the [[Carolina Panthers]] #[[Rip Scherer]] (Class of 1975) â Quarterbacks coach for the [[Carolina Panthers]] #[[Mike Tomlin]] (Class of 1995) â Head coach of the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]]; winner of [[Super Bowl XLIII]]; youngest head coach in NFL history to lead team to Super Bowl win (36 years old) #[[Alan Williams (American football)|Alan Williams]] (Class of 1992) â Defensive backs coach for the [[Indianapolis Colts]] ===Players=== #[[David Caldwell (safety)|David Caldwell]] (Class of 2010) â Strong safety for the [[Indianapolis Colts]] align=center | '''Total''' || '''3 bowl games''' || '''1â2''' || || '''51''' || '''60''' |} ==Football Halls of Fame inductees== ===College Football=== #[[Jack Cloud]] â Set a school scoring record of 102 points in 1947 and once scored five touchdowns in a single game #[[Bill Fincher]] â Did not attend W&M, but coached the Indians in 1921 #[[Lou Holtz]] â Did not attend W&M, but coached the Indians from 1969â1971 and led the team to the [[1970 Tangerine Bowl]] #[[Bill Ingram]] â Did not attend W&M, but Ingram began his coaching career at William & Mary where, in 1922, he managed a 6â3â0 record #[[Buster Ramsey]] â In his four years (1939â1942) the school had a record of 29â7â3; the 1942 team were Southern Conference champions, beating out [[Duke Blue Devils football|Duke]] and [[North Carolina Tar Heels football|North Carolina]] for the title ===National Football League (NFL)=== #[[Lou Creekmur]] â After playing for the Indians he went on to become of one the most successful [[offensive tackle]]s in [[Detroit Lions]] history #[[Marv Levy]] â Did not attend W&M, but coached William & Mary for five years (1964â68), earning two [[Southern Conference]] Coach of the Year awards and one SoCon title ([[1966 William & Mary Tribe football team|1966]]); the 27â16 win over [[Navy Midshipmen football|Navy]] in 1967 is considered by the NCAA to be one of the Top 10 greatest college football upsets in history ===Canadian Football League (CFL)=== #[[Pinball Clemons|Mike "Pinball" Clemons]] â compiled 4,778 all-purpose yards and was named a Division I-AA All-American #[[Ralph Sazio]] â was a mainstay of the Canadian Football League's [[Hamilton Tiger-Cats]] as a player, assistant coach, head coach, general manager and team president ==All-time NFL Draft selections==
